<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	These amounts have been reflected in Other loss, net in the Consolidated Statement of
	Operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	While Time Warner has recognized all declines that are believed to be other-than-temporary as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, it is reasonably possible that individual investments in the Company&#146;s portfolio may experience other-than-temporary declines in value in the future if the underlying investees experience adverse changes in their
	financial condition or poor operating results or if there is a significant decline in the market value of a debt or equity security held by the Company in relation to its cost basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

	TIME WARNER INC.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	A fair value measurement is determined based on the assumptions that a market participant would use in pricing an asset or
	liability. A three-tiered hierarchy draws distinctions between market participant assumptions based on (i)&nbsp;observable inputs such as quoted prices in active markets (Level 1), (ii)&nbsp;inputs other than quoted prices in active markets that are
	observable either directly or indirectly (Level 2) and (iii)&nbsp;unobservable inputs that require the Company to use present value and other valuation techniques in the determination of fair value (Level 3). The following table presents information
	about assets and liabilities required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, respectively (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	Consists of investments related to deferred compensation.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company primarily applies the market approach for valuing recurring fair value measurements. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016
	and 2015, assets valued using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3) primarily related to warrants to purchase shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock of CME valued at $159 million and $179 million, respectively. The Company estimates the fair value
	of these warrants using a Monte Carlo Simulation model. Significant unobservable inputs used in the fair value measurement at December&nbsp;31, 2016 are an expected term of 0.82 years and an expected volatility of approximately 54%. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the other Level 3 assets consisted of equity instruments held by employees of a former subsidiary of the Company. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, Level 3 liabilities consisted of liabilities for contingent
	consideration and options to redeem securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	105
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other Financial Instruments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s other financial instruments, including debt, are not required to be carried at fair value. Based on the
	interest rates prevailing at December&nbsp;31, 2016, the fair value of Time Warner&#146;s public debt exceeded its carrying value by approximately $2.238 billion and, based on interest rates prevailing at December&nbsp;31, 2015, the fair value of
	Time Warner&#146;s public debt exceeded its carrying value by approximately $2.490 billion. The fair value of Time Warner&#146;s public debt is considered a Level 2 measurement as it is based on observable market inputs such as current interest
	rates and, where available, actual sales transactions. Unrealized gains or losses on debt do not result in the realization or expenditure of cash and generally are not recognized in the consolidated financial statements unless the debt is retired
	prior to its maturity. See Note 9 for a discussion of the Company&#146;s debt tender offers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Information as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 about the Company&#146;s investments in CME that are not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis is as follows (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The fair values of the Company&#146;s investments in CME&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock (including Series A convertible
	preferred stock) and Series B convertible redeemable preferred shares are primarily determined by reference to the December&nbsp;31, 2016 closing price of CME&#146;s common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The carrying value for the majority of the Company&#146;s other financial instruments approximates fair value due to the
	short-term nature of the financial instruments or because the financial instruments are of a longer-term nature and are recorded on a discounted basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Non-Financial Instruments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The majority of the Company&#146;s non-financial instruments, which include goodwill, intangible assets, inventories and
	property, plant and equipment, are not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. However, if certain triggering events occur (or at least annually for goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets), a non-financial instrument is
	required to be evaluated for impairment. If the Company determines that the non-financial instrument is impaired, the Company would be required to write down the non-financial instrument to its fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company performed an impairment review of a broadcast license at an
	international subsidiary of Turner. As a result, the Company recorded a noncash impairment of $25 million to write down the value of the asset to $10 million. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 the Company performed an impairment review of
	certain intangible assets at an international subsidiary of Turner. As a result, the Company recorded a noncash impairment of $1 million to completely write off the value of these assets. The resulting fair value measurements were considered to be
	Level 3 measurements and were determined using a DCF methodology with assumptions for cash flows associated with the use and eventual disposition of the assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company also performed fair value measurements
	related to certain theatrical films and television programs. In determining the fair value of its theatrical films, the Company employs a DCF methodology that includes cash flow estimates of a film&#146;s ultimate revenue and costs as well as a
	discount rate. The discount rate utilized in the DCF analysis is based on the weighted average cost of capital of the respective business (e.g., Warner Bros.) plus a risk premium representing the risk associated with producing a particular
	theatrical film. The fair value of any theatrical films and television programs that management plans to abandon is zero. Because the primary determination of fair value is made using a DCF model, the resulting fair value is considered a Level 3
	measurement. The following table presents certain theatrical film and television production costs, which were recorded as inventory in the Consolidated Balance Sheet, that were written down to fair value (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	$
</TD>

</TD>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:26%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	Includes the costs of certain programming rights, primarily sports, for which payments have been made prior to
	the related rights being received.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	Does not include $518 million and $656 million of acquired film library intangible assets as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, respectively, which are included in Intangible assets subject to amortization, net in the Consolidated Balance Sheet.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Approximately 93% of unamortized film costs for released theatrical and television content are expected to be amortized within
	three years from December&nbsp;31, 2016. In addition, approximately $2.5 billion or 67% of the film costs of released and completed and not released theatrical and television product are expected to be amortized during the twelve-month period ending
	December&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DERIVATIVE INSTRUMENTS AND HEDGING ACTIVITIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Time Warner uses derivative instruments, primarily forward contracts, to manage the risk associated with the volatility of
	future cash flows denominated in foreign currencies and changes in fair value resulting from changes in foreign currency exchange rates. The principal currencies being hedged include the British Pound, Euro, Australian Dollar and Canadian Dollar.
	Time Warner uses foreign exchange contracts that generally have maturities of three to 18 months to hedge various foreign exchange exposures, including the following: (i)&nbsp;variability in foreign-currency-denominated cash flows, such as the
	hedges of unremitted or forecasted royalty and license fees owed to Time Warner&#146;s domestic companies for the sale or anticipated sale of U.S. copyrighted products abroad or cash flows for certain film production costs denominated in a foreign
	currency (i.e., cash flow hedges), and (ii)&nbsp;currency risk associated with foreign-currency-denominated operating assets and liabilities (i.e., fair value hedges).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company also enters into derivative contracts that economically hedge certain of its foreign currency risks, even though
	hedge accounting does not apply or the Company elects not to apply hedge accounting. These economic hedges are used primarily to offset the change in certain foreign-currency-denominated intercompany debt due to changes in the underlying foreign
	exchange rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	108
</P>

</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The translation of revenues and expenses denominated in the functional
	currency of a foreign subsidiary may result in fluctuations in the U.S.&nbsp;Dollar-equivalent value of such revenues and expenses as compared to prior periods. Such transactions are not eligible for qualifying hedge accounting treatment, and the
	Company does not economically hedge this exposure.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

	Amounts included in Other loss, net include the impact of forward points and option premiums,
	which are excluded from the assessment of hedge effectiveness. Other amounts included in Other loss, net relate to hedge of foreign-currency-denominated debt and hedge ineffectiveness, which are not material.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company monitors its positions with, and the credit quality of, the financial institutions that are party to its financial
	transactions and has entered into collateral agreements with these counterparties to further protect the Company in the event of deterioration of the credit quality of such counterparties on outstanding transactions. Additionally, netting provisions
	are included in agreements in situations where the Company executes multiple contracts with the same counterparty. For such foreign exchange contracts, the Company offsets the fair values of the amounts owed to or due from the same counterparty and
	classifies the net amount as a net asset or net liability within Prepaid expenses and other current assets or Accounts payable and accrued liabilities, respectively, in the Consolidated Balance Sheet. The following is a summary of amounts recorded
	in the Consolidated Balance Sheet pertaining to Time Warner&#146;s use of foreign currency derivatives at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015 (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

	Includes $297 million ($272 million of qualifying hedges and $25 million of economic hedges) and $153 million
	($141 million of qualifying hedges and $12 million of economic hedges) of foreign exchange derivative contracts in asset and liability positions, respectively.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	(b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	Includes $198 million ($194 million of qualifying hedges and $4 million of economic hedges) and $121 million
	($116 million of qualifying hedges and $5 million of economic hedges) of foreign exchange derivative contracts in asset and liability positions, respectively.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, $46 million and $29 million of gains, respectively, related to cash flow
	hedges are recorded in Accumulated other comprehensive loss, net and are expected to be recognized in earnings at the same time the hedged items affect earnings. Included in Accumulated other comprehensive loss, net at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 are net losses of $3 million and $9 million, respectively, related to hedges of cash flows associated with films that are not expected to be released within the next twelve months.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the carrying amount of the Company&#146;s &#128;700&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of debt
	due 2023 is designated as a hedge of the variability in the Company&#146;s Euro-denominated net investments. The gain or loss on the debt that is designated as, and is effective as, an economic hedge of the net investment in a foreign operation is
	recorded as a currency translation adjustment within Accumulated other comprehensive loss, net in the Consolidated Balance Sheet. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, such amounts totaled $39 million of gains and $1 million of gains,
	respectively. See Note 9 for more information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	109
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LONG-TERM DEBT AND OTHER FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s long-term debt and other financing arrangements consist of revolving bank credit facilities, a commercial
	paper program, fixed-rate public debt and other obligations. The principal amounts of long-term debt adjusted for premiums, discounts and issuance costs consist of (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s unused committed capacity as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $5.162 billion,
	including $1.539 billion of Cash and equivalents. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were no borrowings outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facilities, as defined below, and $1.394 billion of commercial paper was outstanding under the commercial
	paper program. The Revolving Credit Facilities, commercial paper program and public debt of the Company rank pari passu with the senior debt of the respective obligors thereon. The weighted-average interest rate on Time Warner&#146;s total debt was
	4.97% and 5.65% at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Revolving Credit Facilities and Commercial Paper Program
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Revolving Credit Facilities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On December&nbsp;16, 2016, Time Warner amended its $5.0 billion of senior unsecured credit facilities (the &#147;Revolving
	Credit Facilities&#148;), which consist of two $2.5 billion revolving credit facilities, to extend the maturity dates of both facilities from December&nbsp;18, 2020 to December&nbsp;18, 2021 and eliminate the swingline loan subfacility included in
	one of its facilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The permitted borrowers under the Revolving Credit Facilities are Time Warner and Time Warner
	International Finance Limited (&#147;TWIFL&#148; and, together with Time Warner, the &#147;Borrowers&#148;). The interest rate on borrowings and facility fees under the Revolving Credit Facilities are the same for both revolving credit facilities
	and are based on the credit rating for Time Warner&#146;s senior unsecured long-term debt. Based on the credit rating as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the interest rate on borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facilities would be LIBOR plus
	1.10%&nbsp;per annum and the facility fee was 0.15%&nbsp;per annum.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Revolving Credit Facilities provide same-day
	funding and multi-currency capability, and a portion of the commitment, not to exceed $500 million at any time, may be used for the issuance of letters of credit. The covenants in the Revolving Credit Facilities include a maximum consolidated
	leverage ratio covenant of 4.5 times the consolidated EBITDA, as defined in the Revolving Credit Facilities, of Time Warner, but exclude any credit ratings-based defaults or covenants or any ongoing covenant or representations specifically relating
	to a material adverse change in Time Warner&#146;s financial condition or results of operations. The terms and related financial metrics associated with the leverage ratio are defined in the Revolving Credit Facilities. At December&nbsp;31, 2016,
	the Company was in compliance with the leverage covenant, with a consolidated leverage ratio of approximately 2.85 times. Borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facilities may be used for general corporate purposes, and unused credit is available to
	support borrowings by Time Warner under its commercial paper program. The Revolving Credit Facilities also contain certain events of default customary for credit facilities of this type (with customary grace periods, as applicable). The Borrowers
	may from time to time, so long as no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing, increase the commitments under either or both of the Revolving Credit Facilities by up to $500 million per facility by adding new commitments or
	increasing the commitments of willing lenders. The
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	110
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage112"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300508D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	obligations of each of the Borrowers under the Revolving Credit Facilities are directly or indirectly guaranteed, on an unsecured basis, by Historic TW Inc. (&#147;Historic TW&#148;), Home Box
	Office and Turner. The obligations of TWIFL under the Revolving Credit Facilities are also guaranteed by Time Warner.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Commercial Paper Program
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has a commercial paper program, which was established on February&nbsp;16, 2011 on a private
	placement basis, under which Time Warner may issue unsecured commercial paper notes up to a maximum aggregate amount not to exceed the unused committed capacity under the $5.0 billion Revolving Credit Facilities, which support the commercial paper
	program. Unsecured commercial paper notes issued by the Company typically mature in less than 90 days. Proceeds from the commercial paper program may be used for general corporate purposes. The obligations of the Company under the commercial paper
	program are directly or indirectly guaranteed, on an unsecured basis, by Historic TW, Home Box Office and Turner. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had $1.394 billion of commercial paper outstanding, which is supported by the Revolving
	Credit Facilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Public Debt
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Time Warner and one of its subsidiaries have various public debt issuances outstanding. At issuance, the maturities of these
	outstanding series of debt ranged from five to 40 years and the interest rates on debt with fixed interest rates ranged from 1.95% to 9.15%. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the weighted average interest rate on the Company&#146;s outstanding
	fixed-rate public debt was 5.23% and 5.67%, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s fixed-rate public debt had maturities ranging from 2017 to 2045.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Debt Offerings
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On May&nbsp;10, 2016, Time Warner issued $800 million aggregate principal amount of 2.95% Notes due 2026 under a shelf
	registration statement. The net proceeds to the Company from the debt offering were $785 million, after deducting underwriting discounts and offering expenses. On December&nbsp;8, 2016, Time Warner issued $1.5 billion aggregate principal amount of
	3.80% Notes due 2027 under a shelf registration statement. The net proceeds to the Company from the debt offering were $1.487 billion, after deducting underwriting discounts and offering expenses. All of the notes issued are guaranteed, on an
	unsecured basis, by Historic TW. In addition, Turner and Home Box Office guarantee, on an unsecured basis, Historic TW&#146;s guarantee of the notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Debt Tender Offers
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On December&nbsp;14, 2016, Time Warner purchased through cash tender offers $3.0 billion aggregate principal amount of its
	outstanding debt from the following series: 7.700% Debentures due 2032, 7.625% Debentures due 2031, 6.500% Debentures due 2036 and 6.625% Debentures due 2029, each of which continues to have amounts outstanding. The premiums paid and costs incurred
	in connection with this purchase were $1.008 billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and were recorded in Other loss, net in the Consolidated Statement of Operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Maturities of Public Debt
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s public debt matures as follows (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" ALIGN="CENTER">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300508D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Covenants and Credit Rating Triggers
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Each of the credit agreements for the Revolving Credit Facilities (the &#147;Credit Agreement&#148;) and the Company&#146;s
	public debt indentures contain customary covenants. A breach of the covenants in the Credit Agreement that continues beyond any grace period constitutes a default, which can limit the Company&#146;s ability to borrow and can give rise to a right of
	the lenders to terminate the Revolving Credit Facilities and/or require immediate payment of any outstanding debt. A breach of the covenants in the public debt indentures beyond any grace period constitutes a default, which can require immediate
	payment of the outstanding debt. There are no credit ratings-based defaults or covenants in the Credit Agreement or public debt indentures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The interest rate on borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facilities and the facility fee are based in part on the
	Company&#146;s credit ratings. Therefore, if the Company&#146;s credit ratings are lowered, the cost of maintaining the Revolving Credit Facilities and the cost of borrowing increase and, conversely, if the ratings improve, such costs decrease. As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s investment grade debt ratings were as follows: Fitch BBB+, Moody&#146;s Baa2, and S&amp;P BBB.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company was in compliance with all covenants in the Credit Agreement and its public debt
	indentures. The Company does not anticipate that it will have any difficulty in the foreseeable future complying with the covenants in its Credit Agreement or public debt indentures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other Obligations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Other
	long-term debt obligations consist of capital lease and other obligations, including committed financings by subsidiaries under local bank credit agreements. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the weighted average interest rate for other long-term
	debt obligations was 3.18% and 3.32%, respectively. Other long-term debt obligations of $125 million mature in 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Capital Leases
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has entered into various leases primarily related to network equipment that qualify as capital lease obligations.
	As a result, the present value of the remaining future minimum lease payments is recorded as a capitalized lease asset and related capital lease obligation in the Consolidated Balance Sheet. Assets recorded under capital lease obligations totaled
	$118 million and $125 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. Related accumulated amortization totaled $64 million and $81 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Future minimum capital lease payments at December&nbsp;31, 2016 are as follows (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage115"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300508D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_51"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Significant components of Time Warner&#146;s net deferred tax liabilities are
	as follows (millions):
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:26%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	The Company has recorded valuation allowances for certain tax attribute carryforwards and other deferred tax
	assets due to uncertainty that exists regarding future realizability. The tax attribute carryforwards consist of $97 million of tax credits, $74 million of capital losses and $264 million of net operating losses that expire in varying amounts from
	2017 through 2036. If, in the future, the Company believes that it is more likely than not that these deferred tax benefits will be realized, the valuation allowances will be recognized in the Consolidated Statement of Operations.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	U.S. income and foreign withholding taxes have not been recorded on permanently reinvested earnings of
	certain foreign subsidiaries aggregating approximately $1.6 billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Determination of the amount of unrecognized deferred U.S. income tax liability with respect to such earnings is not practicable.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For accounting purposes, the Company records equity-based compensation expense and a related deferred tax asset for the future
	tax deductions it may receive. For income tax purposes, the Company receives a tax deduction equal to the stock price on the date that an RSU (or PSU) vests or the excess of the stock price over the exercise price of an option upon exercise. The
	deferred tax asset consists of amounts relating to individual unvested and/or unexercised equity-based compensation awards; accordingly, deferred tax assets related to certain equity awards may currently be in excess of the tax benefit ultimately
	received. The applicable accounting rules require that the deferred tax asset related to an equity-based compensation award be reduced only at the time the award vests (in the case of an RSU or PSU), is exercised (in the case of a stock option) or
	otherwise expires or is canceled. This reduction is recorded as an adjustment to Additional paid-in capital (&#147;APIC&#148;), to the extent that the realization of excess tax deductions on prior equity-based compensation awards were recorded
	directly to APIC. The cumulative amount of such excess tax deductions is referred to as the Company&#146;s &#147;APIC Pool.&#148; Any shortfall balance recognized in excess of the Company&#146;s APIC Pool is charged to Income tax provision in the
	Consolidated Statement of Operations. The Company&#146;s APIC Pool was sufficient to absorb any shortfalls such that no shortfalls were charged to the Income tax provision during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014. See Note 1 for
	a discussion of accounting guidance for share-based payments that became effective January&nbsp;1, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	114
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company recognizes income tax benefits for tax positions determined more likely than not to be sustained upon examination,
	based on the technical merits of the positions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Changes in the Company&#146;s uncertain income tax positions, excluding
	the related accrual for interest and penalties, from January&nbsp;1 through December&nbsp;31 are set forth below (millions):

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Should the Company&#146;s position with respect to these uncertain tax positions be upheld,
	the significant majority of the effect would be recorded in the Consolidated Statement of Operations as part of the Income tax provision.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company recorded an increase to interest reserves in the Consolidated
	Statement of Operations of approximately $58 million and made interest payments in connection with settlements reached during 2016 of approximately $17 million. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company recorded an increase to
	interest reserves in the Consolidated Statement of Operations of approximately $55 million and made interest payments in connection with settlements reached during 2015 of approximately $19 million. The amount accrued for interest and penalties as
	of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 was $423 million and $382 million, respectively. The Company&#146;s policy is to recognize interest and penalties accrued on uncertain tax positions as part of income tax expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In the Company&#146;s judgment, uncertainties related to certain tax matters are reasonably possible of being resolved during
	the next twelve months. The effect of the resolutions of these matters, a portion of which could vary based on the final terms and timing of actual settlements with taxing authorities, is estimated to be a reduction of recorded unrecognized tax
	benefits ranging from $0 to $270 million, which would lower the Company&#146;s effective tax rate. The Company does not otherwise currently anticipate that its reserves related to uncertain income tax positions as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 will
	significantly increase or decrease during the twelve-month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2017; however, various events could cause the Company&#146;s current expectations to change in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company recognized a tax benefit of $687 million primarily related to the
	reversal of certain tax reserves, including related interest accruals, in connection with a Federal tax settlement on the examination of the Company&#146;s 2005&#150;2007 tax returns. Certain matters involving the Company&#146;s capital loss
	carryforward and research and development tax credits were not resolved as part of the settlement and, accordingly, the Company is pursuing resolution of such matters through the Internal Revenue Service&#146;s (&#147;IRS&#148;) administrative
	appeals process.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company and its subsidiaries file income tax returns in the U.S. and various state and local and
	foreign jurisdictions. The IRS is currently conducting an examination of the Company&#146;s U.S. income tax returns for the 2008 through 2014 period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company filed a petition with the United States Tax Court on a matter relating to the appropriate tax characterization of
	stock warrants received from Google Inc. in 2002. In December 2014, the Company reached a preliminary agreement with the IRS, subject to agreement regarding certain necessary computations and the preparation and execution of definitive
	documentation.&nbsp;In February 2016, the parties reached a final agreement to resolve this matter.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	115
</P>

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_53"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the tax years that remain subject to
	examination by significant jurisdiction are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SHAREHOLDERS&#146; EQUITY
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Common Stock Repurchase Program
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

	Rule 10b5-1 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, and their cost are as follows (millions):

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In January 2016, Time&nbsp;Warner&#146;s Board of Directors authorized up to $5.0 billion of
	share repurchases beginning January&nbsp;1, 2016, including amounts available under the Company&#146;s prior stock repurchase program at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Purchases under the stock repurchase program may be made on the open market or in
	privately negotiated transactions, with the size and timing of these purchases&nbsp;based on a number of factors, including price and business and market conditions. In connection with entering into the Merger Agreement, the Company discontinued
	share repurchases under the stock repurchase program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Shares Authorized and Outstanding
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, shareholders&#146; equity of Time&nbsp;Warner included 772&nbsp;million shares of common stock (net
	of 880&nbsp;million shares of common stock held in treasury). As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, Time&nbsp;Warner is authorized to issue up to 750&nbsp;million shares of preferred stock, up to 8.33 billion shares of common stock and up to
	600&nbsp;million shares of additional series of common stock. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, shareholders&#146; equity of Time&nbsp;Warner included 795&nbsp;million shares of common stock (net of 857&nbsp;million shares of common stock held in
	treasury).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Comprehensive Income (Loss)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Comprehensive income (loss) is reported in the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income and consists of Net income and
	other gains and losses affecting shareholders&#146; equity that, under GAAP, are excluded from Net income. For Time&nbsp;Warner, such items consist primarily of foreign currency translation gains (losses), unrealized gains and losses on certain
	derivative financial instruments and equity securities, and changes in benefit plan obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	116
</P>

<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	13.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<B>
	EQUITY-BASED COMPENSATION
</B>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Equity Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The
	Company has one active equity plan, the Time Warner Inc. 2013 Stock Incentive Plan (the &#147;2013 Stock Incentive Plan&#148;), which was approved by the Company&#146;s stockholders on May&nbsp;23, 2013. Under the 2013 Stock Incentive Plan, the
	Company is authorized to grant equity awards to employees and non-employee directors covering an aggregate of approximately 36&nbsp;million shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. Stock options and RSUs have been granted to employees and
	non-employee directors of the Company. Generally, stock options are granted with exercise prices equal to the fair market value on the date of grant, vest in four equal annual installments, and expire ten years from the date of grant. RSUs granted
	under the 2013 Stock Incentive Plan generally vest in four equal annual installments, while RSUs granted under the Company&#146;s prior stock incentive plans generally vest 50% on each of the third and fourth anniversaries of the date of grant. The
	Company also has a PSU program for executive officers who are awarded a target number of PSUs that represent the contingent (unfunded) right to receive shares of Company common stock at the end of a three-year performance period based on the
	performance level achieved by the Company. Stock options and RSUs generally provide for accelerated vesting upon an election to retire after reaching a specified age and years of service, as well as in certain additional circumstances for
	non-employee directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	118
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage120"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300508D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In connection with entering into the Merger Agreement, the Company has
	granted special retention restricted stock units (&#147;Special Retention RSUs&#148;) to certain employees of Time Warner and its divisions, including all executive officers of Time&nbsp;Warner. Half of the Special Retention RSUs will vest
	25%&nbsp;per year on each of the first four anniversaries of February&nbsp;15, 2017, and the remaining half will vest 25%&nbsp;per year on each of the first four anniversaries of February&nbsp;15, 2018. Pursuant to the Special Retention RSU
	agreements, vesting as a result of retirement is not permitted unless the employee retires after the merger has closed. In addition, the awards do not accelerate automatically following the closing of the merger.&nbsp;Instead, the employee must
	remain employed following the closing, and the awards will vest only upon the scheduled vesting date or upon termination of employment under certain circumstances, such as termination without cause, for good reason or due to retirement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Holders of RSUs are generally entitled to receive cash dividend equivalents based on the regular quarterly cash dividends
	declared and paid by the Company during the period that the RSUs are outstanding. Beginning with RSU grants made in 2013, the dividend equivalent payment for holders of RSUs subject to a performance condition is made in cash following the
	satisfaction of the performance condition. Holders of PSUs also are entitled to receive dividend equivalents based on the regular quarterly cash dividends declared and paid by the Company during the period that the PSUs are outstanding. The dividend
	equivalent payment is made in cash following the vesting of the PSUs (generally following the end of the applicable performance period) and is based on the number of shares that vest and are paid out. Holders of stock options do not receive
	dividends or dividend equivalent payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Upon the (i)&nbsp;exercise of a stock option, (ii)&nbsp;vesting of an RSU or
	(iii)&nbsp;vesting of a PSU, shares of Time&nbsp;Warner common stock may be issued either from authorized but unissued shares or from treasury stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In connection with the Time Separation and in accordance with existing antidilution provisions in the Company&#146;s equity
	plans, the number of stock options, RSUs and target PSUs outstanding at the Distribution Date and the exercise prices of such stock options were prospectively adjusted to maintain the value of those awards subsequent to the Time Separation (the
	&#147;Adjustment&#148;). The changes in the number of shares subject to outstanding equity awards and the exercise prices were determined by comparing the value of such awards immediately prior to the Time Separation to the value of such awards
	immediately after the Time Separation. Accordingly, the number of shares subject to each equity award outstanding as of the Distribution Date was increased by multiplying such number of shares by a factor of approximately 1.04, while the per share
	exercise price of each stock option was decreased by dividing such exercise price by a factor of approximately 1.04. The adjustments resulted in an increase of approximately 2&nbsp;million shares subject to outstanding equity awards following the
	Time Separation. The adjustments to the outstanding equity awards did not result in any additional compensation expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Other information pertaining to each category of equity-based compensation appears below.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the number, weighted-average exercise price, aggregate intrinsic
	value and weighted-average remaining contractual term of the aggregate Time Warner stock options that either had vested or are expected to vest approximate the corresponding amounts for options outstanding. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016,
	approximately 14&nbsp;million shares of Time&nbsp;Warner common stock were available for future grants of stock options under the Company&#146;s equity plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

	Table of Contents

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_64"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table sets forth the total intrinsic value of RSUs and target
	PSUs that vested during the following years (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="61%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Total unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested Time&nbsp;Warner stock option awards
	as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, without taking into account expected forfeitures, is $53 million and is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period between 1 and 2 years. Total unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested RSUs and
	target PSUs as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, without taking into account expected forfeitures, is $621 million and is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period between 1 and 2 years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BENEFIT PLANS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Time&nbsp;Warner Pension Plan Amendment
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On August&nbsp;1, 2016, the Time&nbsp;Warner Pension Plan was amended to provide a window for a one-time lump sum payment for
	eligible vested participants who (i)&nbsp;had terminated employment as of May&nbsp;31, 2016, (ii)&nbsp;had not yet commenced payment of their benefits as of May&nbsp;31, 2016, (iii)&nbsp;are not otherwise eligible for an immediate lump sum payment
	of their benefits and (iv)&nbsp;have benefits with a present value of less than $50,000. Eligible participants had the opportunity to elect, during the period beginning on August&nbsp;16, 2016 and ending on October&nbsp;7, 2016, to receive their
	benefits in the form of an immediate lump sum payment. Certain annuity options were also available. Payments to those eligible participants who elected to receive their benefit under the window program were made or commenced in December 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	121
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage123"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the funded status for substantially
	all of Time&nbsp;Warner&#146;s domestic and international defined benefit pension plans recognized in the Consolidated Balance Sheet reflected a net liability position of $727 million and $741 million, respectively, primarily consisting of
	noncurrent liabilities of $837 million and $798 million, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, amounts included in Accumulated other comprehensive loss, net were $1.335 billion and $1.402 billion, respectively,
	primarily consisting of net actuarial losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Certain defined benefit pension plans have projected benefit obligations
	and accumulated benefit obligations in excess of their plan assets. These plans are primarily unfunded. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the projected benefit obligations for unfunded plans were $414 million and $417 million,
	respectively, and the accumulated benefit obligations for unfunded plans were $407 million and $410 million, respectively. In addition, as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the projected benefit obligation and accumulated benefit obligation for certain
	funded plans exceeded the fair value of their assets by $457 million and $455 million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	122
</P>

<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	Amounts relate to various international benefit plans.
</P>

<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	Excludes net periodic benefit costs related to discontinued operations of $12 million, $5 million and $3
	million during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively, primarily related to employees and former employees of Time Inc. These amounts have been reflected in Other loss, net in the Consolidated Statement of Operations. In
	addition, net periodic benefit costs for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 also excludes $46 million of pension settlement charges related to businesses the Company previously disposed of.&nbsp;These amounts have been reflected in Discontinued
	Operations, net of tax, in the Consolidated Statement of Operations.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Assumptions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Weighted-average assumptions used to determine benefit obligations and net periodic benefit costs for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="40%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>

<TD>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The discount rates were determined by matching the plan&#146;s liability cash flows to rates
	derived from high-quality corporate bonds available at the measurement date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In developing the expected long-term rate of
	return on plan assets, the Company considered long-term historical rates of return, the Company&#146;s plan asset allocations as well as the opinions and outlooks of investment professionals and consulting firms.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	123
</P>

</TR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company primarily utilizes the market approach for determining recurring fair value
	measurements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s defined benefit pension plans&#146; investment policy is to minimize the volatility of
	the plans&#146; funded status and to achieve and maintain fully funded status in order to pay current and future participant benefits from plan assets. The Company periodically reviews asset allocation policies consistent with its investment policy.
	In addition, the Company continuously monitors the performance of its pension assets, the performance of its investment advisers, sub-advisers and asset managers thereof, and makes adjustments and changes as required. The Company does not manage any
	pension assets internally. The investment guidelines set by the Company for the investment advisers, sub-advisers and asset managers permit the use of index funds, derivative contracts and other hedging strategies as components of portfolio
	management strategies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Under the Company&#146;s investment policy, the asset allocation target for the funded domestic
	defined benefit pension plan is approximately 40% equity investments and 60% fixed income investments. As and when funded status and market conditions permit, the Company intends to move 5% of the fixed income investments to equity investments
	comprised of growth assets for each 5% decline in the funding level until the fixed income investment allocation reaches a minimum of 50% of the plan&#146;s assets. In addition, should funding improve over time, 5% of the growth assets would be
	moved to fixed income investments for every 5% increase in funding level toward a target of approximately 20% equity investments and 80% fixed income investments to further minimize funded status volatility. The plan&#146;s growth assets will be
	further diversified over time to include real estate funds that invest in high quality properties with a small degree of leverage. Target asset allocations for the international defined benefit pension plans as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 are
	approximately 30% equity investments, 50% fixed income investments and 20% other investments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At both December&nbsp;31,
	2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the defined benefit pension plans&#146; assets did not include any securities issued by Time Warner.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Expected cash
	flows
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	After considering the funded status of the Company&#146;s defined benefit pension plans, movements in the
	discount rate, investment performance and related tax consequences, the Company may choose to make contributions to its pension plans in any given year. The Company made discretionary cash contributions totaling approximately $40 million to one of
	its funded international defined benefit pension plans during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. For the Company&#146;s unfunded plans, contributions will continue to be made to the extent benefits are paid.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Information about the expected benefit payments for the Company&#146;s defined benefit plans is as follows (millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<A NAME="eolPage127"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D300508D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	TIME WARNER INC.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS - (Continued)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Defined Contribution Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Time Warner has certain domestic and international defined contribution plans, including savings and profit sharing plans, for
	which the expense amounted to $149 million in 2016, $153 million in 2015 and $160 million in 2014. The Company&#146;s contributions to the savings plans are primarily based on a percentage of the employees&#146; elected contributions and are subject
	to plan provisions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other Postretirement Benefit Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In July 2013, the Company discontinued subsidized medical benefits provided to all future retirees who were employed on
	December&nbsp;31, 2013 and who would not have met the eligibility criteria by December&nbsp;31, 2015 and effective January&nbsp;1, 2014, post-65 retiree medical coverage was discontinued and eligible retirees were moved to coverage provided in the
	individual health insurance market.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Time Warner also sponsors several unfunded domestic postretirement benefit plans
	covering certain retirees and their dependents. For substantially all of Time Warner&#146;s domestic postretirement benefit plans, the unfunded benefit obligation as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $88 million and $93
	million, respectively, and the amount recognized in Accumulated other comprehensive income, net was a gain of $19 million and $19 million, respectively. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, the net periodic benefit costs were
	$1 million, $2 million and $2 million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Multiemployer Benefit Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company contributes to various multiemployer defined benefit pension plans under the terms of collective-bargaining
	agreements that cover certain of its union-represented employees, primarily at the Warner Bros. segment. The risks of participating in these multiemployer pension plans are different from single-employer pension plans in that (i)&nbsp;contributions
	made by the Company to the multiemployer pension plans may be used to provide benefits to employees of other participating employers; (ii)&nbsp;if the Company chooses to stop participating in certain of these multiemployer pension plans, it may be
	required to pay those plans an amount based on the underfunded status of the plan, which is referred to as a withdrawal liability; and (iii)&nbsp;actions taken by a participating employer that lead to a deterioration of the financial health of a
	multiemployer pension plan may result in the unfunded obligations of the multiemployer pension plan being borne by its remaining participating employers. While no multiemployer pension plan contributed to by the Company is individually significant,
	the Pension Protection Act of 2006 zone status as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 (i.e., for the multiemployer pension plan&#146;s 2015 plan year) of all of the largest multiemployer pension plans in which the Company participates was green, which implies
	that such plans are funded at a level of 80 percent or greater. Total contributions made by the Company to multiemployer pension plans for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 were $128 million, $139 million and $124 million,
	respectively. Included in the amounts for 2015 and 2014 are contributions of less than $1 million in each year that Home Box Office made to the Radio, Television&nbsp;and Recording Arts Pension Fund (&#147;RT&amp;RA Plan&#148;) under a collective
	bargaining agreement that expired in October 2015.&nbsp;In&nbsp;February 2016, Home Box Office completed the negotiation of a new collective bargaining agreement under which it is no longer be required to make contributions to the RT&amp;RA
	Plan.&nbsp;As a result, Home Box Office has withdrawn from the RT&amp;RA Plan and recorded a $9 million charge in Selling, general and administrative expenses during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 for its withdrawal liability.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company also contributes to various other multiemployer benefit plans that provide health and welfare benefits to active
	and retired participants, primarily at the Warner Bros. segment. Total contributions made by the Company to these other multiemployer benefit plans for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 were $194 million, $220 million and $205
	million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	126
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company incurred costs in connection with the
	2016 initiatives of $61 million at the Turner segment, $47 million at the Home Box Office segment, $2 million at the Warner Bros. segment and $4 million at Corporate. In addition, in connection with the 2015 initiatives, the Company incurred costs
	of $1 million at the Home Box Office segment. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company also incurred costs of $1 million at the Home Box Office segment and $2 million at the Warner Bros. segment, and reversed $1 million at Corporate
	related to 2014 and prior initiatives. The amount recorded by the Company in 2016 for both the 2015 initiatives and the 2014 and prior initiatives consisted of changes to estimates of previously established accruals as well as new charges related to
	those initiatives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company incurred costs in connection with the 2015
	initiatives of $58 million at the Turner segment, $15 million at the Home Box Office segment and $3 million at Corporate. In addition, in connection with the 2014 and prior initiatives, the Company incurred costs of $1 million at the Warner Bros.
	segment and reversed $15 million at the Home Box Office segment and $2 million at Corporate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	127
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:26%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	Noncash reductions relate to the settlement of certain employee-related liabilities with equity instruments.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, of the remaining $171 million liability, $114 million was classified as a
	current liability in the Consolidated Balance Sheet, with the remaining $57 million classified as a long-term liability. Amounts classified as long-term are expected to be paid through 2019.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	16.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SEGMENT INFORMATION
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Time&nbsp;Warner classifies its operations into three reportable segments:
<I>
	Turner
</I>
	: consisting principally of cable
	networks and digital media properties;
<I>
	Home Box Office
</I>
	: consisting principally of premium pay television and OTT services domestically and premium pay, basic tier television and OTT services internationally; and
<I>
	Warner Bros.
</I>
	:
	consisting principally of television, feature film, home video and videogame production and distribution. Time&nbsp;Warner&#146;s reportable segments have been determined in accordance with its internal management structure and the financial
	information that is evaluated regularly by the Company&#146;s chief operating decision maker.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In the ordinary course of
	business, Time&nbsp;Warner&#146;s reportable segments enter into transactions with one another. The most common types of intersegment transactions include the Warner Bros. segment generating revenues by licensing television and theatrical
	programming to the Turner and Home Box Office segments. While intersegment transactions are treated like third-party transactions to determine segment performance, the revenues (and corresponding expenses or assets recognized by the segment that is
	the counterparty to the transaction) are eliminated in consolidation and, therefore, do not affect consolidated results.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	128
</P>
